so I ended up using LunarVim.

This is the C and assembly code for the key1 function.

So, the pc value will then be the value for key1

will then be the value

If we just take a quick look at what pc is:

  1. Right, so when a CPU executes a
    single instruction,
    itâ€™s said to go through
    the fetch, decode, and execute stages.

  2. To execute two opcodes,
    youâ€™d then need a total of six operations:
    fetch, decode, execute, fetch, decode, execute.

  3. By performing these stages in
    parallel, however, you can reduce those
    six operations needed for two opcodes
    down to just four.

  4. Itâ€™s simply more efficient than doing it
    sequentially, you see.
    The Program Counter,or PC,
    holds the address for the fetch operation.

  5. If the current instruction is at
    the execute stage,
    the next one will be at the decode stage,
    and the one after that will
    then be at the fetch stage.

  6. Consequently,
    the PC will then hold the address of
    the instruction thatâ€™s
    due for the next fetch operation.

Right, back to the main point now.

The pc value in the key1 function is

0x00008ce4

is.

one just needs to find it.

0x1a770

as an integer.

input it into the blank space,

As soon as the mission is completed,

2 points have been snagged.

then, if you go back to the initial screen again,

dotted line

entry.content:
[pwnable.kr]_Memcpy Problem solving

Right then, haha. Every problem I pick,

|ì°¸ê³  ì‚¬í•­|

Screenshot.1

Alright, then. If
I just do a rough-and-ready literal translation of the passage,
it goes something like this:

â€‹

Are you tired of hacking?, take some rest here.

(ìœ¼ë”° í•´í‚¹í•˜ëŠ” ê±° ì§€ê²¨ì›Œì¡Œê³  ë§ˆì´ ì ê¹ ì¢€ ì‰¬ë‘ê»˜?)

(memcpy ì„±ëŠ¥ ì‹¤í—˜ ì¢€ ë„ì™€ë‹¬ë‘ê»˜)

â€‹

after that, flag is yours.

(ê·¸ëŸ¼ í‚¤ê°’ì€ ë‹ˆêº¼ë‘ê¼?)

â€‹

Right then. Apparently,
itâ€™s not a hack this time around.
Still, best to have a look, wouldnâ€™t you say?

Screenshot.2

Right then. As before, just fire up your terminal, get yourself connected,

and then, naturally, youâ€™ll employ the trusty

command to have a gander at the files.
Is ls
â€‹

Right. So,itâ€™s just memcpy and readme,is it?
Thatâ€™s your lot.
Doubt weâ€™ll be snagging any keys from this account,then.

Screenshot.3

Right, then. Looks like weâ€™ll
probably need a temporary bit of privilege escalation,
likely via an nclistener, to get our hands on that key.

Screenshot.4

Right then. Letâ€™s just hop onto that listener.
And as soon as weâ€™re in,

youâ€™ll see memcpy is running.
Turns out, this fileâ€¦

â€‹

It appears to be operating as a C function,
then, designed for copying memory.

Screenshot. 5

The memcpy file apparently takes
numbers within a given range.

Feed it anything outside that,
and it just bails immediately.

But get ten in-range numbers into it,
and then itâ€™s said to perform both a
â€‹
slow and a fast memory copy process.

Right. It only gets through five stages of that process,
and then suddenlyâ€¦

Then it just spat out an error and promptly died. ÅxÅ
Then it just spat out an error and promptly died. ÅxÅ

Right. So, what weâ€™ve found is this program has a tendency to
just cut out mid-process.
And,as the messages on execution rather plainly suggest

itâ€™s all tied to the slow and fast memcpy implementations.

â€‹
Right. Apparently,
if you can compare
the various data sizes without it cutting out mid-process,

and manage to get through all the sections,
itâ€™s said to hand over the key.

So,I suppose weâ€™d better dive into the source code, then.

Right. So, back in experiment5,
the fast_memcpy section threw an error, didnâ€™t it?
That just cut off the rest of it.

Means we can only actually get the key if all
the subsequent sections run through without a hitch.

1. It runs ten times, as per the input count.

2. Memory is dynamically allocated to the set size,
and thatâ€™s stored in dest.

3. The rdtsc() function, for precise timing, calculates
the duration of the slow memory copy and puts that into t1.

4. And t2, of course, will then hold the time taken for the fast memory copy.

5. Right. So, the slow memory copy, thatâ€™s done byte by byte.
The fast one? Thatâ€™s block by block.

â†’ Solution : First off, weâ€™ll need those functions where
the slow and fast memory copies are actually defined.

Right. Youâ€™ll need to head over to that section and
figure out what the functionâ€™s actually doing.

Next slow\_memcpy, fast\_memcpyItâ€™s a function.

Right. slow\_memcpy,
thatâ€™s your basic byte-by-byte operation
from source to destination.
Simple enough, but a bit sluggish,
mind you. fast\_memcpy(), on the other

hand, well, thatâ€™s designed for 64-byte chunksâ€¦
â€‹
Right then. If itâ€™s anything under that,
it just runs slow\_memcpy.
But for 64 bytes or more,
it then executes the assembly-level code

Right then. In the fast\_memcpy() section,
it cut out midway through execution, didnâ€™t it?
That meant this assembly code simply wasnâ€™t able to

properly get invoked, thus throwing an error.
â€‹

Right. The analysis breaks down as follows.

movdqa : Right.Theâ€™Aligned Double Quadword Moveâ€™.

Right. It takes the double quadword from the source operand
â€”thatâ€™s your secondâ€”and moves it to
the destination operand, which is the first one.
â€‹
Right then.
This instruction moves a double quadword between an XMM
register and a 128-bit memory location,
or between two of thoseâ€¦
â€‹
â€¦XMM registers. And, naturally,
it can be used for movement between those.
Now, regarding the source or destination operandâ€¦

Right. If your operandâ€™s memory-based,
it absolutely has to be aligned to a 16-byte boundary.
Fail to do that, and youâ€™ll get yourself a
General Protection Exception (#GP).

â€‹

movntps : Right then.
Thatâ€™s for storing packed single-precision floating-point values,
utilising that non-temporal hint, of course.

then. Youâ€™re using the non-temporal hint to move
the packed floating-point values from the source operand,
over to the destination.

â€¦operand, and that, naturally,
prevents any data caching whilst itâ€™s being written to memory.

â€‹

Right then. In movdqa
theâ€™movâ€™bit there is,of course,
your instruction for shifting values about.
Andâ€™dqâ€™? Well,thatâ€™s just yourâ€™double quadâ€™, isnâ€™t it?

Right then.
That instruction, itâ€™ll throw an exception if itâ€™s not aligned to
a 16-byte boundary.So, if you just ensure

the destination operandâ€™s address is 16-byte aligned,
thatâ€™ll sort the issue right out.

â€‹
Right then. Weâ€™ll just fire up GDB,debug it,
and then go about snagging that key, wonâ€™t we?
ã…‹ã……ã…‹

Screenshot. 6

Right then. Once weâ€™ve executed that through GDB,
weâ€™ll then step into the fast\_memcpy function and have a proper look, shall we?

Screenshot. 7

Right then. Itâ€™s sat at that location,
and the EDX value is 0x080487cc.

Up to the fourth instance,
the alignment was perfectly fine,

so no errors popped up.
But the fifth one? It wasnâ€™t aligned at all.

Screenshot. 8

Right then. Just set a breakpoint at
the fast\_memcpy function,
specifically at +71. Check the register value,
and youâ€™ll find EDX is indeed aligned at 804d060

â€‹
Essentially,
itâ€™s 8 bytes short of 64,
meaning youâ€™ll need an 8-byte offset.

And for any other values youâ€™re debugging,
itâ€™s fair to assume theyâ€™ll
all be missing 8 as well.

â€‹

So, weâ€™ll just add eight to the fifth value and
every subsequent one after thatâ€¦

â€‹

8 16 32 64 128 256 512 1024 2048 4096

8 16 32 72 136 264 520 1032 2056 4096

â€‹
then.
So, itâ€™ll assume that form weâ€™ve just established.

And armed with that little theory of ours,
weâ€™ll then just fire up an nclistening serverâ€¦

â€‹
â€¦feed each of those in, and then youâ€™ll finally manage to snag the key.

â€‹
Right. One could,naturally,dabble with other approaches,
I suppose.But for my money,using GDB is probably
the most sensible way to go about it.

â€‹
So, if you run the program,
youâ€™ll find the key value displayed, much as below.

Screenshot. 9

With the key value weâ€™ve just, ah,â€™snaggedâ€™,
you simply head back to the start,pop it into
the blank,and then,naturally,hit thatâ€™authâ€™ button.

Screenshot.10

Right.
And then youâ€™re presented
with a message about securing 10 points





Screenshot.11

then. And upon returning,
youâ€™ll find itâ€™s indicated
with a green dotted line.
Signifying itâ€™s, well, resolved.

â€‹

And thanks for actually
bothering to read through all that.

Right then.Thatâ€™s done, then. :)

Right then.
Hope your day isnâ€™t completely rubbish,
and whatever youâ€™re cracking on with goes smoothly.

Itâ€™s a bit of a scorcher today,mind you,
so try not to go getting heatstroke.
And, naturally,
do be careful of that Wuhan pneumonia.

entry.content:
Wowâ€¦ I had a feeling, but the difficultyâ€™s on another level.

Îµ-(Â´ãƒ»ï½€)

war games on Wargame.kr in terms of difficulty.

I ended up referring to someone elseâ€™s

solution while working through it.

And since posting the actual

source code would make the thread messy,

Iâ€™ll place it in a text file so it can simply be copy-pasted.

Anyway, letâ€™s get started right away.




Right, if Iâ€™m having a punt at roughly translating
the gist of this in my own way,
itâ€™s something like this:
So, youâ€™re on about MD5 hash collisions then,
are we? (Â·Â·Â·) Right,anyway.



Right then, first things first,
open up yer Linux terminal.
Then you just wanna connect using

Now,the password right?
It wonâ€™t actually show up as youâ€™re typing it
â€“ donâ€™t mind that,just bash it in,hit Enter,
and bam, youâ€™re logged in. Easy peasy!



Right then next up,you just wanna whack in

the ls command to see what files youâ€™ve got lurking around.

Now col youâ€™d probably reckon thatâ€™s
some sort of executable or maybe even a Python file, right?

But the actual one we really need to be bothered with,

the crucial bit, is col.c




so if you have a proper gander at the main bit,

the password, right, that needs to be 20

characters long. And hereâ€™s the crucial part:
the hash code (0x21DD09EC) and

the password return value,
theyâ€™ve both gotta be

absolutely spot on, exactly the same.
No messing about with that, understood

That
bash check_password(const char* p)
Bit, Yeah?
What itâ€™s doing is, itâ€™s taking chunks of the data
like, 4 bytes at a time â€“ thatâ€™s the size of an int, innit?
â€“ and itâ€™s then accumulating those into â€˜resâ€™ five times.

So, the thinking is,
if you just add the exact same value five times over you should,

I reckon, get that hash code itâ€™s after. Simple as that, really.

Derivation of results

Figure.1) For and res data expressed by cutting int type 4 bytes each

Right, so thatâ€™resâ€™value,yeah?

Thatâ€™s just the result of piling up
whatever came out of the â€˜forâ€™loop,
five times over.
And if you then,like,divvy thatâ€™resâ€™value by five,
it turns out that the data

so if you then like,multiply this lot by five again
youâ€™ll find youâ€™re short by 0x4.So,
the assumption weâ€™re making here is

that the data is essentially four lots of
0x6C5CEC8 and then one bit of 0x6C5CECC added in.

Figure. 2> Data expressed in little endian

then,since itâ€™s all about little endian,yeah?
All you need to do is just feed the program that data
in hexadecimal,in the exact sequence.
Thatâ€™s the one.

then, so you've gone and chucked the value in hexadecimal

using Python for that, yeah?

Now, hereâ€™s the kicker, mind you:
when the program picks that up as an input
itâ€™ll jolly well recognise it as a char.
So, you just gotta watch out for that. Proper careful,like.

Flag

Right then, so we've finally bagged the key value.

And with this rather handy key weâ€™ve just nabbed
itâ€™s back to the very beginning, isnâ€™t it?


Right then, for that 'Flag?' bit down below,
